interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and some English) texts have an English summary, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to printed texts.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing a double re‐keying method when typed out. In addition, all re‐keyed texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
All words have been retained as written in the source text even when there are apparent errors in either spelling or when there has been either an omission in punctuation or grammar.

In such cases missing words or letters have not been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

A reference system has been built up using the identifiers of the following text units: text, division, paragraph. Each nested division has an identifier which is built up by successively adding to the identifier of the text. Each paragraph has an identifier which adds yet another layer to the immediately superordinate identifier.

langUsage.language: Approximately 95% of the texts are Scottish Gaelic, 2.5% of the texts are in Irish Gaelic and the remainder being roughly divided between English and Scots.

DonDonald Campbell of Airds
was J PJustice of the Peace & preached every day.
it was his turn to save his
pay & stipend. He came
over to Lismore & brought his
barge to Portramasey
Gave instinstructions to his gillean
dubha to catch his black
sheep in Ramasey & put
its skins on faradh na
Bachuill. Done. The
follingfollowing day & the black sheep
was missing. He gave out
a warrant to search all
houses. The skins was
found on the rafters of
the Baron. There was
much weeping & wailing
lament & shame. The
BBaron was to be hanged. Well
said Sir John you are
an old faith paid to the
church & I feel shame stain
that such a slanslander should
be cast upon the religion
I preach & serve and upon
your family. I will go
to InvInveraray & do all I can to
save your being hanged –
on concondition however that
you will assign over
to me UcUchd a Chlachain
Crois Duill Garadh

div.title: Aird bhea'aichbheathaich
div.p:
Donl DuDonald Dubh was so troubletroublesome
that his own father drove
him frfrom his house – His
father came to see him
to Airds & his gents. They
were all going along at
the Luirgnich & DoDonald said
I know you will not
gavegive me much of what
you have fathfather. O not one
thing DonlDonald. Well I ask you
to give me the power of
pit & gallows as you have
it yourself. No. If not
I will make you that
you will not have
it long. You have
not hanged a man
ever. As they walked
along they saw three
men coming out of the wood
each with a cabar on his
shouldshoulder. Do you see those
said DonlDonald Du.Dubh. If you
do not hang them I
will break your office
Where did you get those
cabers said DDonald DDubh.
had you perpermission. yes. We
always have perpermission to take
cabers for cliacliath chliat –
Who fid marked them
out to you. No one. Do
you hear that ye art
said DDonald DuDubh. If you do
not hang them I ll hang
you (to his fathfather. The
The Tighearna Challairt
had (comas stoc us croich in
all Argyle Shire. Two of the men
tall & one short. H Father
tupput the two men on their
knees & put a running
noose round neck of
little man & put a caber
through noose. These men
then rose. Witness ye
gentlemen that I hanged
these men. There is no
po obligobligation upon me to hang
them dead. After some
struggle the man was
all right. Do your
utmost now DDonald DuDubh
said his fathfather.

Till lately all the people
of Sir Johns in LismLismore
need permipermission to take fiodh
cliacliath chliat from
Airds.

On his death bed he called for the Baron. His wife (no wife) asked his wife
to send for him. She did but sent a messmessanger after him saysaying he need not go. He asked her if she sent and she said she sent. O am Baron am Baron he roardroared rather than called Tha ghaoil bha gaoil agads air a bheiradhbheireadh riabhriamh. &c & He died.

div.title: Legacy.
div.p:
Duncan & James Stewart sons
of AlexAlexander Stewart son of DuncDuncan son taoitear writer
(heir) of Stewart of Appin.
After Culloden where
they fotfought they fled to Jamaica.
They got on as planters
& sent £1000 to a bank aat
Greenock (Union?) and
the interest to be paid to their
father & mother. Their father
was Morison was AlexAlexander Stewart
& their mother Mary (?) Macdonald.
These got this legaceylegacy as long as they
lived & lived at Airdsheile
Appin. After their death
no more came. Then
the sister of these Jamaica
men after they died of
sunstroke set to work
and got their money
from Jamaica. She
went to Duneiden several
times for it & got it. Never got
the Greenock legacy.
MaighMaighread Stewart was her name
mmarried to Donald MacCombaich
in Torasey. His son DunDuncan
was in Gibraltar. & Dr G. S. Mac
leod used to be in his house
there. Mary MacCombaich
her datdaughter marrmarried DonDonald Black
who went to Torosey where
he marmarried her datdaughter MaighMaighread
Black marmarried to Donald
Macintire, Achnanduin.

the people the plaugeplague. Fish
found among others at Kil
chiaran was soft & thrown
to the cats. all died im-
mediately.

Daughter
of the caistealan went
to see her lover in Island
& her father told her he
wuldwould shoot her. He killed
her as she was crossing the
Doirlinn her body buried
in Cladh a ghleann
-ain Another cladh at
Pillebhudh on a beaut
fulbeautiful knoll.

Càbag was in island
& not far from to Lismore
Appin &c but always
found in BearnyBearneray in ring
The fiodhan as this was
called was carved in
stone. At last boatboatmen
threw it out at Lighe-
sgeir & there it restrests. Got
at Temple – built of lime
Cairn near.

Port ban an eilean
below which cra'iun.
Terrific storm arose

div.p:
Invernahyle Appin
Sunday 18 AugAugust 1883
Saw the small bit left of old
Invernahyle house
18 x 12 feet outside and some
five feet high. Thatched roof
door on gable & used as
milk house by the farmer
Mr Mackean.
Got drink of milk in this
house. Here Sir Walter
Scott wortewrote Waverley
or 60 yrsyears ago. Close by is
Craobh a Phrionnsa
where it is said Prince
Charles was in hiding. In
Ardsheal is Uaimh
Phrionnsa also in hiding
there. There are lengthlengthy
traditions still of Scott

div.title: Lòni – Cure
div.p:
Kill a dog suddenly – or
unknown to the dog –
boil the piece of the fat
dip flannel in this and
place it over the part
affected. Mrs Stewart
from Prince EEdward Island
CuredCured by an Indian doctor.

Cancer on one in ten in
PPrince EEdward IslIsland. Cure plaster
applied early – leaves
out all rootlets.

At the solemn feast which
celebrated his son's knighthood
Edward vowed on the
Swan which formed the
dniestdaintiest dish at the banquet
to devote the rest of his days
to exact vengeance from
the murderer himself.

Cloichlea. Removed to
to Clachan for him
manse on prestpresent site.
People used to play

saw them in his way to
church – Come with myself
said he – If you come
with us first I will & he
went. These cdrenchildren saw
& they went & so by degrees

wife hanged herself at
Cloichlea on SundySunday morgmorning
as he was praying to go to AppAppin
to preach. He went
after all. He had Eilean
Dubh Tirphuir. All
the ministministers till Mr Stewart
came had this isle – & some
of Tirphuir.

div.title:
Baran Na Bachuil
Agus na 2 Ighnean Rua
div.p:
Stewart of AppAppin went to a
greanachas to Duart
& his valet. There they were
trying at marks & Stewarts man
was best. The gillean
maola dubha bha riabhriamh
ri olc an Dubhairts
were jealous & they caught
& flayed alive a piece of
his skin. & were laughing
over it. 'Isnt he white'
isnt he fat’ Chan ann
eir bairnich dhubh
nan creag tha mo ghille
tintighinn beo said StewtStewart. They
killed him & hung him
up against the wall
of the castle. The baron
of Bachuil & his 2 redred-haired
datdaughters took boat at Port
Chailleach the southmost
port on West of Lismore –
They made holes on all the
boats at Duart & carried
off the body – 2 versions
That when Stewart missed
his man who had been walkwalking beside
him he heard laughing in a
cuil closet. They chased him
& he threw off jumped out
at Stac-lia. Swam to Carraig
called now Sgeir na
Baintiarna They saw him
& followed & came up to him
his skin glancing in the
bright sunshine – at
Sgeir nan Gaol Bainne
na Srathrach An t Srathan
the tide there – They killed him
with the oars thothough he was
diving like a dooker. They
buried him in Cillepharuig
near the castle Duart.
The baron took merchant
over & was selling it till he
found out his grave. He
made them all drunk –
& took up bones. He got ashore
& buried the body under
the sand at Port bhailla
Achnanard
This Stewart body is the
one nearest the church
at Clachan & beside it
on the north side is Donul
nan Ord. Another near
that Fear na h-Apun
is inside the church on
north-east side.

Fear Achnacrois brotbrought Irish
from Ireland to work at
lint in Lismore. This
was my relation.

The Romhanach built the first
church. Buried 1 at the
church 2 at Carn Iain
Ghallda – the Taigh chlachan
& 3 at Croc FhionnlaiFhionnlaidh
– south side of

The exonerated man from
Druim an UUinnsinn was put round
Sunwise the eala
the eala one for simple fault
for woseworse 2 & three times for
gross alleged fault. If
found guilty but not exexonerated
he was put round once for
simple fault against
the sun. Bha urram
mhor mhor dol leis
a ghrein.

in form of cresentcrescent on underlower

Eacara = The place where
a pounder puts cattle
horses & sheep after
pounding. Place of this
name in Lismore at Lon-
more (Eacara = For horses?)

One of these at Moine

breac.

lg.l: The sow and geordie ran a race
Geordie fell & broke his face
The sow she ran & won the race
And turned her tail to Geordie's face

A magnimagnificent looking Lismore
woman living in Kingussie
quarquarelled with another. And
making a luthadh mor
said Gu de is urrainn
daibh a gh rath rium ach
gun toil liom na fir –
mu's toil is toil leis na
fir mi!

About 1918 years ago this
AutAutumn, my brother Dugald
Macintire aged 44(?) took
typhus fever & in eight
days he was dead. My
husband DunDuncan Campbell
took fever & in as short
a time died. Each went
out on a Tuesday – 1
3 weeks between. I drag-
ged both their bodies out
& put them in the coffin
on the field. & I weak
watching them & fighting
with them for they came
strong & feverish. My
nephew DonDonald Mac
corquodale aged abtabout 13
was down & pulled throthrough
brothers & sister's boy DunDuncan
Macintire aged 4 yrsyears was
down – but pulled throthrough.
Mary Carmichael aged
30 30 abtabout 30 was down – A
cousin of weak weakmind I
then lay in fear & lay
unconscious for 3 weeks
& till begbeginning of spring was weak.
I crept on my magain
to eadar da bhi an doruis
The carts carrying away
our corn were passing
our door but I could not
see them being weak. The
cattle then were all away
– driven away by DonlDomhnall
Iain bhain. We had
4 cows, 1 horse good 2 queys
2 stirks 1 pet lamb which
I fed from the gogan.
The crop was good.

When I came my service
on the GalldacGalldachd my mother
& brother were £31. That I paid.
A few years before my
brother died (3 yrsyears) my
brobrother lost the price of a hosehorse
while retingreturning from market
This threw us about £8 in
arrears. We got no
warning & no sale was
made – either of crop
or stock. When I got
well all I had left were
a few hens – neither of
stock nor of crop. pota
Potatoes & corn gone –
I aftafterwards gott one from
Gregor. I got the byre
of a neighneighbour Dugald
BauchannBuchanan Who had been
similarly served. Our
neighneighbours Donald & Maol-
Moire Black brothers were
not a penny in arrears.
Their farm ours and
Dugald BuchBuchanan. were put
out & one farm made
of the whole Tirphuir
now in posspossession of CapCaptain CamCampbell
Oban.

Who kept you up there
Bha Ni math fear a
b urrainn – I got paid
relief for my sister lawsister-in-law's
boy & when Early in Spring
I was delivered of a boy – I was
abtabout 8 momonths marmarried When
my boy was abtabout 9 yrsyears I saw
I could give him no scholschool
so I had to appapply for relief –
This contcontinued abtabout 5 yrsyears.

A brobrother of eaeach of these two men
were the first to have a vessel
in Lismore. They used to
trade to Ireland where
each married & had children.
Come to Lismore & GlasGlasgow

Cill an t-Suidhe?

Donald MacColl

an ribi no more splendid men

than the Lismore men.
Canbhuch Lismore people

div.head: Creag Chuirulain
div.p:
Cuirulan = One of the old
saints or sagairt – most
of the MacColls of Appin
Sgeir a Phobuill – in
in (Incis = Level plain)
Loch creagan in coille – close
to shore. Tobar Ch
hall Chuiralain Tobar a
ghluin in a rock. for healing
of leg diseases. Tobar nan
sul for sore eyes. Clach
an Droma – for healing
of Leum droma – leaned
back against this stone –
(knew I was north from my
Gaelic!). Natural all
the things they had whwhere at
Creag Chuiralain –
put here half penny or
silver under the rock in the
buthailt (recess). Tobar
a Ghlun is cut in a rock
like a basin or pot smooth
ly cut & stone lid. Tobar
an sul issues from
under a rock.

Two tribes Clann ic
ille ruitich (Reds
Clann ic ill Ruai?
Riuas) & another tribe
trysted to give battle there
The Reds came in upon
the others while resting
& killed many. They were
buried there & the priests

div.p:
The fairies carried her away from her
lea-shiulaleabaidh-shiula. There was a man in Blar
nan laogh Ach-nan-con, Appin.
He went to Duror for whisky. In retingreturning he
laid down the jar & made water. This
Chuala e "ocaid" eir sgioblachadh
a bhreacain. He looked down & saw his own
wife whom he carried home - & placplaced
in the barn. When he went in his
own mother & his wifewife's mothmother were
in great distress about his un-returned
wife. He cautcaught her by caol nan cas
& dragged her throthrough a large fire & she was
a black stoc daraich in the door.
This was what the sith placplaced in his
wifes bed when they carried her away.
He placed his wife in her bed. She
was delivdelivered before he left. That is why they
are so keen to take women for their
milk to feed the clann nan sith.
Urine stops fairy cantrips.
'Is meirg a leigeadh ucuchd ri tailean.'
When the old black fairy was thrown in the
glumag was by the woman. When
the tailor told her he was a fairy
when he made the fuarag.

Roebucks throw themselves
throthrough between wires of fence
without touching wire
up or down. They throw
themselves on their side
in the most clever manner.

Farm Constable
elected by baile yearly at Caingeis
They make nabacnabachd elect
a majority when they don't agree.
He gives his word of honour
that he will be true & honest
to the communitcommunity. If day be wet
he sees that no one goes cartgcarting peats on
the mormoorland for there in its puddles
it alsalso cuts up ridh utraid He
does not allow one man to go fem-
anadh nor lifting potpotatoes nor
dlu'adh. When that man
is done he allows his cattle to
go free & so allows them to eat cuid
chaich. He goes to catch horses
in towns land & asks them to meet
say at Clach na comhairle
to put in coideadar – If by
day – if at night in a house
in middle of bo baile. He
has to see that the cuidhe is up
& sub.subdivided. Each croft has a peighinpeighinn
of this cuidhe to keep up. If day
be wet he orders the herd to
sentsend the cattle from the
Geary to the machair the

other soft. Ere they begin

people. The utraid is divddivided

Last winter the Bermuda a fine ship was
wrecked there. It was a fearful
night – & bitterly cold with a driving
sleet & with the snow thick on the
ground. AftAfter passing days & nights
in mental anxiety & aftafter havhaving
narrnarrowly escaped that of their frequency
had almost removed a sense
of dangdanger frfrom the capcaptain running the ship
was wreckdwrecked on a lee shore. By
alalmost a miracle the capcaptain, his wife
& little datdaughter & the crew were saved.
But the scene of lawlessness at
the wreck was something indescribindescribable.
Everybody began to "rifle rob and
plunder" & such was the effect
on the crew of the vessel that
not the recent escapes from
peril they joined in & plundered
too. But the worst remains to be
told. The capt'scaptain's wife & child two
helpless creatcreatures half dead with
fright & cold bewildered by this
terrible danger they had passed
& scared by the hellish sights
& noises around them stood
benumbed in the snow
& piercing wind. Their
boots were taken off from off their feet
& their wrappings & covergscoverings
frfrom their bodies – & in that
state they might have
perished. The capcaptain resisted
& appapplied in vain for help. He
was powerless. The people
believed that proprovidence had sent
them another harvest.
Should they not glean
it while they could & while
they were permitted by
the Island authorities?

a seat for the heir said all

div.title: Native Dyes
div.p:
Black is made from
the cart-loch in Skye called
logaire – as in the song
"Bha i fo gu da chruachan
S i ri buain an logaire"
The cairt loch is the water lillylillie
that grows in lakes in from
3 to 4 feet water and most
difficult to get at.

The cairt loch roots are boiled
and the lithe is put in and
again boiled with the wool.
The wool is then taken up and dried.

The dubhach, duich &c
is a marl, ashen grey, got
in various places in the Long IsldIsland
as at Cleite-nan-dubhacha
Harris, SSouth Hacleit, Cailtinish
Seilebhagh, Ionnair and
other places – This is a dun
yellow kind of mud or earth.
It lies in alternate layers
or ordinary mud.

This dubhach duiche is
boiled with the wool dyed
with ththe cart loch & fastens the
dye. The colour is fast and
remains good to the last. Black
is also fastened by using iris
roots copperass rusty nails
or rust.

The duiche is boiled in the
"lithe" "lye" or the cairt loch
– hard very hard till it stops
boiling over and all rheum
(rèum Gaelic) is off. The surface
then becomes bare and pitpitch black.
The wool is then boiled in this
"lye"’ for a quarter of an hour
or so slowly.

Yellow is made from
the top of the green young heathheather
not from fraoch a bhan
bhain – The best is the young
heathheather growing after heather
burning or falasg. Alum
is boiled with the wool
first – then the heather tops are
put in and boiled hard for
1½ hours or so for each
lucluchd poit

Sealastair, iris, makes
two colours – the top lacunnlachdunn
slatyslatey grey the root reddish
brown. Requires cairt to
make it fast.

lg.l:
"Laidhidh an dubhach air
gach dath

Ach cha laidh dath air
an dubhaich dhuibh."

div.p:
SootsShoots makes a deep lively brown
Dith mu seach sootshoot & wool
are put in the pot & boiled.
Crotal makes a deep reddish
brown. The crotal & wool
are put in dith mu seach –
layer about & boiled. No
alum. Crotal is healthy
next the skin & is used for
semets and stockings. Mrs
Gordon dyed semets and
sox with crotal for her
husband John Gordon SSouth Uist.
Rù makes red a soft red
like magenta. This ru is got
in the machairs. The root goes
far down and the root being the
part of the plant – which makes the
dye, there is much demand for it.
Women used to dye it up to
the destruction of the machair.
If caught they were severely pun-
ished and efforts were always
made to detect them by the
factors and ground officers.
These ground officers and
constables went about amongst
the weavers to see if they had
ru dyes in their looms and
if so woe betide the woman
to whom the web belonged!
Experts knew from the appear
ance of the ground where the ru
was to be found, and they dug
accordingly. They followed the
roots down and away to the
end probably for many yards
from where they started. After
a storm and high tide the
roots are laid bare along the
shores of the machairs: Ann
MacintreMacintire IocarIochdar SSouth Uistwent
with her old aunt to dig at
Gualan, Iocar for rù.
The first night the old aunt
broke the crocan the next
night they dug a lot.
Ladies in Uist used to bribe
the old aunt to procure
them rù and would give her
as much as 5/- for half a
bag of roots – There was as much
illegal traffic in ru as in dis-
tillation and as in whisky the
result could not be concealed
Rù requires great care and
cleanliness in making the dye.
Rù and madar are used
for red; carnaid for scarlet
druise, drise for brown
cairt reanna for
Ann Macintire went to
Gualann after the lan mor
of XChristmas 1865 and gathered two
sackfuls sacksful of rù
roots.

div.title: For Toothache
div.p:
The first Biorrach caught
in season – an gath (bior)
was cut with knife off & this
was placed under tooth for
the toothache. The Biorrach
was put out to sea alive
again. Another – A nail
from a grave placed undunder
tooth & after that the nail
was driven into a tree that
was gorm a chuile
lalatha sa bhliadhna. ever
green tree. AnothAnother – A
bonnach was baken of the
spittles put out with the
deideadh & this was sent
to the neighbouring
oighreacoighreachd. Ian Mor
in Ailigan made bior-
anan sticks (3) & placed
under the tooth. These
were kept for future use.
This man put the oraortha
in these bioranan.

live cock feet tied buried
alive & 3 sixpences of
silver a carn was raised

got the tinneas tuitmastuiteamas.
A wo girls here (2 Glen
StStreet EdinEdinburgh) tells me a girl

her & this was done at
Gearrloch.

Also a hole dug &
nettle grew where
the cock was buried
& thothough the placed was

year after year.

div.title: Marriage Customs
div.p:
About the beginning of this century it
was customary in Colonsay to meet
on two hillocks to arrange marriage
preliminaries. On the farm of
they met – the bride's
party on one knoll (cnoc) and
the groom's party on another. Then
one man from each party
descended the valley and came
within speaking distance of one
another. They conversed in solemn
tones and then retired to their respective
parties. They descended the valley
a second time and came nearer
than before and talked again in
a formal manner and then
went back up the hill as before.
The two men met again for
the third and last time and on
this occasion came quite close
to one each other and after a third
and final and formal negociation they
parted.

If either party with-drew the
party withdrawing paid the tochar
agreed upon to the other. In case the
girl withdrew, her father had to pay
his daughter’s tochar; if the man
withdrew he paid the equivalent of
the girl's tochar to the girl and there
was an end to it. Neither lost
cast.

lg.l: Is ann air luba na h-abhunn
Thug sibh an latha
Gur h-ioma fear dra'uisdrabhuis
Bha na laidhelaighe gun eiridh
Bodach Nam BrigisBriogais.

div.p:
Cama-lin, at Midmuir Lorn
near this is Musdal.

lg.l: An toir thu do nighean domh
Chailleach an dudain?
An toir thu do nighean domh
Chailleach an dudain?
An toir thu do nighean domh
Dheanainns mire rithe
An toir thu do nighean domh
Dheanainns mire rithe
Ghleusainn fiodha dhi
S dhannsainn cridheil rithe
Chailleach an dudain!
